comments:
This course is recommended for science majors and engineering students. It covers the classical laws of motion, interactions between particles, conservation laws and symmetry principles, particle and rigid body motion, gravitation, and harmonic motion.

Students thought that this class was a “good starting course for science majors.” They generally described the content of the course as similar to that of AP Physics C – Mechanics.

Most students didn’t find Professor Lipeles particularly engaging. They felt he often seemed “unsure of how to present the material” and “had difficulty communicating his knowledge.” Many also reported he made many mistakes on the board. Others considered him an “excellent professor” who did a good job going over examples in class. Some also mentioned that as the semester progressed, Professor Lipeles “definitely improved” and became much more effective as a teacher.

One student mentioned having to do “a lot of self-reading” to learn the material. Problems were also considered more difficult than those of AP mechanics. Homework is not collected, but students recommended doing all problems to keep up with the class.

This course is recommended for science majors and engineering students and covers the classical laws of motion, interactions between particles, conservation laws and symmetry principles, particle and rigid body motion, gravitation, and harmonic motion.

In general, students described the course as “enjoyable” and felt that they had learned a lot.

Most students felt that Professor Hollebeek was “very good” at communicating the subject matter and giving tips on how to attack the course. Some also liked how he taught new material by deriving formulas and going “step by step through various problems.” However, a few students felt that Professor Holleebeek simplified topics in class but then presented them in depth on homework and exams. Students liked that he was accessible and “always willing to help.”

One student commented that this course is probably “not a good fit” for people only looking to fulfill a basic requirement and who aren’t already interested in physics or haven’t taken AP Physics before. Another student said that you can do well as long as you keep up with the problems in the book. A couple students also mentioned that quizzes were quite hard.

This course is recommended for science majors and engineering students and covers the classical laws of motion, interactions between particles, conservation laws and symmetry principles, particle and rigid body motion, gravitation, and harmonic motion.

Students considered this course to be “valuable” and generally felt that they had learned a lot about mechanics.

Almost all students described Professor Thomson as “energetic,” “kind,” “helpful,” and “accessible.” They almost unanimously agreed that she was a “wonderful instructor.” She was able to teach the subject matter in an “understandable and straightforward” way. Students also liked the pace and organization of the course.

Students found tests hard, but in general, the course itself was “not too difficult” with effort. One student commented that “it would be easy enough for a student to receive an A if they kept up with the work.”

One student commented that this course is probably “not a good fit” for people only looking to fulfill a basic requirement and who aren’t already interested in physics or haven’t taken AP Physics before.
